questions.question: What is React?
questions.answer: React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It allows developers to create reusable UI components and efficiently update and render them when the underlying data changes.

questions.question: What are the key features of React?
questions.answer: Some key features of React include virtual DOM, component-based architecture, one-way data flow, and JSX syntax.

questions.question: What is JSX?
questions.answer: JSX is a syntax extension for JavaScript that allows you to write HTML-like code in your JavaScript files. It is used in React to describe the structure and appearance of UI components.

questions.question: What is the difference between state and props in React?
questions.answer: State is used to manage internal component data that can change over time. Props, on the other hand, are used to pass data from a parent component to its child components.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the componentDidMount() lifecycle method?
questions.answer: The componentDidMount() method is called after a component has been rendered to the DOM. It is commonly used to perform tasks such as fetching data from an API or setting up event listeners.
